s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCARDIFF Bayrsquos entertainment destination, The Red Dragon Centre, has introduced additional health and safety measures with the wellbeing of visitors and staff at the heart.The multitude of measures came as venues inside the complex reopened to the public on Monday, August .Venue managers, Savills Management Resources have worked collaboratively with the Centrersquos leisure and dining occupants, to implement the safety measures in accordance with Welsh government guidelines to reopen safely this week.MORE STORIESBarry balloon artist Doctor Bob goes wild at Cardf Bays Red Dragon CentreBobs balloon creations set to wow thousands at extravaganzaJames pimps his naan for a taste of success!The most dramatic measure in place is a one-way system to ensure that social distancing is maintained and that footfall through the site can be managed.Yellow arrows indicate the direction of travel in the new system, supplemented by a iety of audio and visual reminders including public address system announcements, rope and pole barrier systems, and branded, bilingual signage stationed at each entrance.Venues at The Red Dragon Centre will also be implementing queuing systems to monitor capacity and maintain social distancing within their inidual outlets and in accordance with their risk assessments.Venues including Cadwaladers and Cardf Bay Tavern have reopened their indoor dining facilities, while leisure venues Hollywood Bowl will open on Tuesday, August  and Simply Gym will open on Monday, August .Restaurants Zaika and Five Guys, who have been operating takeaway and delivery services during lockdown, also reopen for indoor dining, with Five Guys joining Cadwaladers and Cardf Bay Tavern in participating in the UK Governmentrsquos lsquoEat Out to Help Out lsquoscheme on Mondays through to Wednesdays.Cadwaladers store manager, Bernadette Cammilleri said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome customers back to our cafeacute for indoor dining.ldquoWersquove been working closely with the Centre on a range of measures to ensure customers feel safe and enjoy their experience when they decide to visit.To mitigate the spread of covid- throughout the Centre, cashless payment systems are in place where possible and an enhanced title: changes made penarth town centre lockdown plans
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. services available again.ldquoWhile increasing numbers of people have been accessing books, resources and activities online, for many the reopening of library buildings will be very welcomelsquoOur library staff have worked hard to provide as many facilities as possible online, but I know they are looking forward to seeing familiar faces and hopefully some new ones too.ldquoResidents will be able to use PCs and visit libraries in person to browse books though both activities will be tightly controlled.ldquoSafety remains the number one priority and all appropriate measures will be in place to protect both library members and staff.During this period, chairs will be removed from the libraries to discourage sitting, toilets will be closed to the public and there will be no meetings, activities or room bookings available.Anyone entering the building will be asked to use hand gel and complete a track and trace card giving their name and contact details.Library staff will work behind protective screens when at a desk and wear visors at other times and all books will be quarantined for  hours before being cleaned and put back into circulation.Current weekday opening times title: a levels results day wales twins off oxford university
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. jeopardise this."That means we are not at a point where we should be visiting anyonersquos home at any time."Regulations on meeting outdoors were recently changed to make it easier to do, and this remains by far the safest way to meet.ldquoThere are also indications from other parts of the UK where pubs opened earlier than Wales that outbreaks have been linked to those places."If we are to title: vj day letter thanks welsh government first minister mark drakeford
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityStan Smith, of Barry, spoke to the deputy minister.Mr Smith was on board ship for VJ day and to this day he remains integral to the work of the Royal British Legion in his hometown, supporting those who have served in the armed forces.MORE STORIESVeterans advice service for Vale ex-service personnel during coronavirus crisisMark the th anniversary of VE Day in the ValeWe will remember themMr Drakeford said: "The surrender of Japan to the Allied forces  years ago, signalled the end of the Second World War."Six years of unprecedented conflict and suffering was finally coming to a close."And the Welsh troops who had been fighting in the Far East and Pacic were toto their beloved homeland once more."I was lucky enough to speak with veterans who served in the Far East during the Second World War over zoom this week."The inspirational stories I heard from Walford Hughes and Ted Owens will stay with me forever, as will their support for fellow veterans readjusting to le after war."Today it is dficult to imagine just how many people were devastated by the legacy of war that raged across this huge expanse of our planet, all the way from Hawaii to India."Tragically, millions of civilians across Asia-Pacic were killed and injured."The first ever nuclear bomb used in war brought devastation to the people of Hiroshima."Its legacy would last for decades to come."Between December  and August , British and Commonwealth forces and their allies engaged in ferocious fighting by land, air and sea, across jungles and remote islands."By the end of the war, , British troops had been killed in the Far East, with three times as many injured."Over , allied troops had suffered brutal conditions as prisoners of war."Those who became prisoners faced harrowing conditions."Some were sent to labour camps in the jungle. Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will mark this important anniversary and pay tribute to all those affected by the war in the Far East and Pacic: Service personnel, their families and all civilians around the world."We pay our tributes to all of those affected by war, in our own extraordinary time, under the shadow of coronavirus, no doubt impacting our usual plans for commemorations."But at a time when we have had to make sacrices and suffered losses, we remember those  years ago who were there at the end of the most destructive conflict the world has ever seen."Those whose sacrice and suffering allowed the next generation to work towards peace."We thank you."We remember you."You will never be forgotten."Get involved:Take part in a two minute silence at am on Saturday, August Celebrate in your own homes ndash for ideas go to title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Disgust as vandals wreck NI beauty spotPolice investigate financial irregularities at churchNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . When we were investing in developing the Wedding Suite we wanted to create a welcoming environment where brides could visit with their bridal party and enjoy the experience of choosing their wedding dress without any pressure.”Anne Crossan, Regional Retail Manager, SVP NI, said: “The new Vincent’s Wedding Suite is a wonderful addition to the service that we are providing to the local community in the Portadown area. story: Police appeal for witnesses after dog knocked downDisgust as vandals wreck NI beauty spotNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsVJ Day event welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important
